medical_record:
EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES RUN REPORT

Patient Name: Jonathan Parker
DOB: 03/22/1987
Sex: Male
Incident Date/Time: 04/02/2025 17:38
Date of Service: 04/02/2025
Run Number: EMS-25-18432

Pickup Location: I-35 Northbound at Exit 247, Austin, TX 78753
Destination Facility: Starlight Regional Medical Center, 2100 W 5th St, Austin, TX 78703

Primary Insurance: Lone Star Auto & Casualty, Claim #LSA-2025-48192
Secondary Insurance: SilverShield Health PPO, Member ID: SSH-77492038-01

CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Motor vehicle collision. Patient was restrained driver rear-ended at highway speed, complaining of neck pain, mid-back pain, and frontal headache.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
38-year-old male involved in rear-end MVC at approximately 17:20. Patient reports being stopped in traffic when struck from behind by a pickup truck. No airbag deployment. Denies loss of consciousness but reports feeling "dazed" for several seconds. Self-extricated from vehicle and was ambulatory on scene. Complaints: 6/10 neck pain radiating to shoulders, 5/10 mid-thoracic pain, mild nausea, and 4/10 frontal headache. Denies chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or extremity numbness/weakness.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
- Hypertension
- Hyperlipidemia

MEDICATIONS:
- Lisinopril 10 mg PO daily
- Atorvastatin 20 mg PO nightly

ALLERGIES:
- NKDA (No known drug allergies)

VITAL SIGNS AT 17:44:
- BP: 148/92 mmHg
- HR: 92 bpm
- RR: 18 breaths/min
- SpO2: 98% on room air
- GCS: 15 (E4, V5, M6)

PHYSICAL EXAM (FIELD):
- General: Alert, oriented x3, mildly anxious, in mild distress due to pain.
- HEENT: Pupils equal, round, reactive to light. No scalp lacerations or hematomas.
- Neck: Midline cervical spine tenderness at C4–C6. No step-offs. C-collar applied.
- Chest: Breath sounds clear bilaterally. No chest wall tenderness.
- Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
- Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no ecchymosis.
- Back: Midline tenderness over T6–T8, no deformity.
- Neuro: Strength 5/5 in all extremities. Sensation intact. No focal deficits.

TREATMENTS PROVIDED:
- Cervical spine immobilization with rigid collar
- Long spine board for transport
- IV access: 18G right antecubital
- Normal saline 0.9% at TKO
- Fentanyl 50 mcg IV at 17:52 for pain (pain improved from 6/10 to 4/10)

TRANSPORT & HANDOFF:
Transported emergently (Code 2) to Starlight Regional Medical Center ED. Handoff report given to RN Sarah Wilcox, RN license #RN-882944, and ED attending Dr. Michael R. Hargrove at 18:09.

BILLING SUMMARY:

| Service Code | Description                         | Units | Charge (USD) |
|-------------|-------------------------------------|-------|--------------|
| A0427       | ALS Emergency Transport             | 1     | 850.00       |
| A0425       | Ground Mileage (per mile)           | 12    | 180.00       |
| A0398       | IV Supplies and Medication Handling | 1     | 95.00        |
| J3010       | Fentanyl Citrate Injection          | 1     | 60.00        |

Provider: EMT-P Daniel Rivera, License #EMTP-21478
Electronic Signature Date: 04/02/2025 19:02

This record is intended for claims processing and medical review by Starlight Regional Medical Center, Lone Star Auto & Casualty (Adjuster: Melissa Grant, Direct Line: 512-555-6231), and SilverShield Health PPO.
user_feedback: Summary should not include full DOB, only their current age and city/state of residence. I also think bullet point would be easier to read.

medical_record:
EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT VISIT NOTE

Facility: Starlight Regional Medical Center
Address: 2100 W 5th St, Austin, TX 78703
ED Encounter #: ED-25-449302
Date of Service: 04/02/2025

Patient: Jonathan Parker
DOB: 03/22/1987
MRN: 001-45-8832
Primary Care Physician: Laura Kim, MD
Auto Insurer: Lone Star Auto & Casualty, Claim #LSA-2025-48192
Health Insurer: SilverShield Health PPO, Member ID SSH-77492038-01

CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Neck pain, back pain, and headache following motor vehicle collision.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
37-year-old male brought in by EMS following rear-end MVC on I-35 at approximately 17:20 on 04/02/2025. Patient was restrained driver, no airbag deployment, no reported loss of consciousness. C-collar in place on arrival. Reports 6/10 neck pain, 5/10 mid-back pain, and 4/10 frontal headache. Denies vision changes, vomiting, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or extremity weakness. No anticoagulant use. Last oral intake around 13:00.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
- Hypertension
- Hyperlipidemia

SURGICAL HISTORY:
- Appendectomy (2010)

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Married, lives with spouse (Emily Parker) and two children at 4112 Brentwood Ln, Austin, TX 78757. Works as software project manager. Social alcohol use, denies tobacco or illicit drug use.

MEDICATIONS (PER PATIENT):
- Lisinopril 10 mg PO daily
- Atorvastatin 20 mg PO nightly

ALLERGIES: No known drug allergies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
- Constitutional: Denies fever, chills.
- Neuro: Positive headache; denies dizziness, syncope, focal weakness.
- Musculoskeletal: Positive neck and mid-back pain; denies extremity deformity.
- Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or palpitations.
- Respiratory: Denies dyspnea.
- GI: Denies abdominal pain, nausea only mild, no vomiting.

VITALS (ED TRIAGE 18:11):
- BP: 152/94 mmHg
- HR: 88 bpm
- RR: 17 breaths/min
- Temp: 98.6°F (37°C)
- SpO2: 99% RA

PHYSICAL EXAM:
- General: Alert, oriented x4, appears uncomfortable but non-toxic.
- Head: Normocephalic, no visible trauma.
- Neck: C-collar in place. Midline tenderness over C4–C6. No step-offs.
- Back: Tenderness over mid-thoracic spine (T6–T8). No ecchymosis.
- Neuro: Cranial nerves II–XII intact. Strength 5/5 in upper and lower extremities. Sensation intact to light touch. Normal gait deferred due to cervical immobilization.
- Chest/Abdomen: Non-tender, breath sounds clear, heart sounds regular.

DIAGNOSTIC STUDIES ORDERED:
- CT Cervical Spine without contrast
- X-ray Thoracic Spine (2–3 views)
- CT Head without contrast (due to headache and mechanism)

MEDICATIONS GIVEN IN ED:
- Ketorolac 30 mg IV at 18:24
- Acetaminophen 1,000 mg PO at 18:30

RESULTS (PRELIMINARY):
- CT Head (04/02/2025 19:02): No acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, or skull fracture. Mild sinus mucosal thickening.
- CT Cervical Spine (04/02/2025 19:10): No acute fracture or malalignment. Mild C5–C6 degenerative disc disease with small posterior disc osteophyte complex. No significant canal stenosis.
- X-ray Thoracic Spine (04/02/2025 19:18): No acute fracture or compression deformity. Preserved alignment.

ED COURSE & MEDICAL DECISION MAKING:
Symptoms consistent with whiplash-type cervical strain and thoracic paraspinal muscle strain. No red-flag findings. Normal neurological exam and negative imaging for acute traumatic injury. Patient observed for ~2.5 hours, remained hemodynamically stable, tolerating PO, ambulated to restroom with mild discomfort only.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Acute cervical strain secondary to motor vehicle collision
2. Thoracic paraspinal muscle strain
3. Post-traumatic headache

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
- Ibuprofen 600 mg PO every 6 hours PRN pain (take with food), #30
- Cyclobenzaprine 5 mg PO at bedtime PRN muscle spasm, #10

FOLLOW-UP INSTRUCTIONS:
- Follow up with primary care physician (Dr. Laura Kim) within 5–7 days.
- Return to ED for worsening pain, weakness, numbness, difficulty walking, severe headache, or any new neurologic symptoms.
- Advised likely soreness for several days.

BILLING & CHARGES SUMMARY:

|--------|----------------------------------------|-------|--------------|
| 99284  | ED Visit, Level 4                      | 1     | 1,250.00     |
| 72125  | CT Cervical Spine w/o contrast         | 1     | 1,100.00     |
| 70450  | CT Head w/o contrast                   | 1     | 950.00       |
| 72070  | X-ray Thoracic Spine                   | 1     | 350.00       |
| J1885  | Ketorolac Tromethamine Injection       | 1     | 65.00        |
| J0131  | Acetaminophen, oral/solution           | 1     | 25.00        |

Attending Physician: Michael R. Hargrove, MD (NPI: 1780645932)
Electronic Signature Date/Time: 04/02/2025 21:07
user_feedback: Their correct age as of 1/1/2026 is 38. Residence should be limited to city and state only, not the full address. on the records we just need a high level breakdown, no need to go into things like vital signs.

medical_record:
DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING REPORT – CT CERVICAL SPINE

Facility: Starlight Regional Medical Center Radiology Department
Address: 2100 W 5th St, Austin, TX 78703
Exam Date / Date of Service: 04/02/2025
Accession #: RAD-25-993201

Patient: Jonathan Parker
DOB: 03/22/1987
MRN: 001-45-8832
Referring Physician: Michael R. Hargrove, MD
Reason for Exam: Neck pain following rear-end motor vehicle collision on 04/02/2025 at approximately 17:20.

TECHNIQUE:
Non-contrast CT of the cervical spine performed with axial images from skull base through T1, with coronal and sagittal reformats.

FINDINGS:
- Alignment: Normal cervical lordosis maintained. No evidence of listhesis.
- Vertebrae: No acute fracture, vertebral body height is preserved at all levels.
- Intervertebral Discs: Mild disc space narrowing and osteophyte formation at C5–C6, consistent with early degenerative disc disease.
- Spinal Canal: No significant spinal canal stenosis. Neural foramina are patent bilaterally.
- Soft Tissues: Prevertebral soft tissues are within normal limits. No paraspinal hematoma.
- Craniocervical Junction: Normal.

IMPRESSION:
1. No acute cervical spine fracture or malalignment.
2. Mild degenerative changes at C5–C6, likely chronic and not directly related to the acute trauma.

Please correlate with clinical findings. If symptoms persist or worsen, consider MRI of the cervical spine.

BILLING SUMMARY:

| Code   | Description                    | Units | Charge (USD) |
|--------|--------------------------------|-------|--------------|
| 72125  | CT Cervical Spine w/o Contrast | 1     | 1,100.00     |
| 76377  | 3D Reconstruction (if applied) | 1     | 250.00       |

Radiologist: Karen L. Mendoza, MD (NPI: 1629487301)
Report Finalized: 04/02/2025 19:15
Signed Electronically by: Karen L. Mendoza, MD
user_feedback: If we have impressions we don't need to include findings as well. However we do need specific objective results from the imaging studies.

medical_record:
PRIMARY CARE FOLLOW-UP VISIT

Clinic: North Austin Family Medicine
Address: 8120 Burnet Rd, Suite 220, Austin, TX 78757
Phone: 512-555-4120
Date of Service: 04/08/2025

Patient: Jonathan Parker
DOB: 03/22/1987
MRN: NAFM-003492
Primary Care Physician: Laura Kim, MD
Auto Claim: Lone Star Auto & Casualty, Claim #LSA-2025-48192

REASON FOR VISIT:
Follow-up after emergency department evaluation for motor vehicle collision on 04/02/2025.

SUBJECTIVE:
Patient reports persistent neck stiffness, mid-back soreness, and new onset intermittent tingling in the right arm when sitting at his desk for prolonged periods. Pain is rated 5/10 in the neck and 3/10 in mid-back, worse at the end of the day. Headaches have improved and now occur only once every 2–3 days. He has been taking ibuprofen 600 mg as directed and cyclobenzaprine at bedtime, which helps with sleep but causes mild morning grogginess.

He denies bowel or bladder changes, significant weakness, or gait disturbance. He returned to work on 04/07/2025 but is avoiding heavy lifting. He and his spouse, Emily Parker, are concerned about potential long-term neck damage.

REVIEW OF RECORDS:
Reviewed ED note from 04/02/2025 and CT imaging reports dated 04/02/2025 (CT head, CT cervical spine, thoracic spine X-ray) showing no acute fractures, with mild pre-existing degenerative changes at C5–C6.

OBJECTIVE:
Vital Signs (04/08/2025 09:14):
- BP: 138/86 mmHg
- HR: 80 bpm
- RR: 16 breaths/min
- Temp: 98.4°F
- BMI: 27.2 kg/m²

Physical Exam:
- Neck: Decreased range of motion in flexion and rotation (about 70% of normal). Tenderness over paraspinal muscles. No midline step-offs.
- Upper Extremities: Strength 5/5 bilaterally. Reflexes 2+ and symmetric. Mild positive Spurling test on the right reproducing tingling into right forearm.
- Back: Tenderness over thoracic paraspinals. No deformity.

ASSESSMENT:
1. Cervical strain following motor vehicle collision (subacute)
2. Possible cervical radiculopathy (right upper extremity paresthesia)
3. Thoracic muscle strain, improving

PLAN:
- Order MRI Cervical Spine without contrast to evaluate for disc herniation or foraminal stenosis.
- Refer to outpatient physical therapy for cervical and thoracic spine rehabilitation (2–3 times per week for 4–6 weeks).
- Continue NSAIDs as needed; advise to avoid exceeding 2400 mg/day of ibuprofen.
- Change muscle relaxant to methocarbamol 500 mg PO at bedtime PRN if drowsiness persists with cyclobenzaprine.
- Work restrictions note provided: Avoid lifting >20 lbs, limit prolonged sitting to <60 minutes without break, effective 04/08/2025–05/08/2025.

BILLING / CHARGES:

| Code   | Description                                  | Units | Charge (USD) |
|--------|----------------------------------------------|-------|--------------|
| 99214  | Office Visit, Established Patient, Level 4   | 1     | 210.00       |
| 72040  | MRI Cervical Spine w/o Contrast (ordered)    | 1     | 0.00*        |

*Note: Imaging billed separately by imaging center.

Provider: Laura Kim, MD (NPI: 1572946102)
Electronic Signature Date: 04/08/2025 10:02
user_feedback: Need to include the work restriction 'avoid lifting >20 lbs'. Don't include DOB, only age as of 1/1/2026.

medical_record:
MRI CERVICAL SPINE REPORT

Imaging Center: Central Texas Advanced Imaging
Address: 9500 Research Blvd, Suite 150, Austin, TX 78759
Phone: 512-555-9030
Exam Date / Date of Service: 04/12/2025
Accession #: CTI-25-552903

Patient: Jonathan Parker
DOB: 03/22/1987
Referring Physician: Laura Kim, MD
Clinical History: Persistent neck pain and intermittent right arm paresthesia following motor vehicle collision on 04/02/2025. Evaluate for disc herniation.

TECHNIQUE:
MRI of the cervical spine performed without intravenous contrast. Sagittal T1, T2, STIR; axial T2-weighted images.

FINDINGS:
- Alignment: Normal cervical alignment.
- Cord: Normal signal and caliber throughout.
- C2–C3: Unremarkable.
- C3–C4: Minimal disc bulge without significant canal or foraminal stenosis.
- C4–C5: Mild disc bulge with mild right foraminal narrowing.
- C5–C6: Broad-based right paracentral disc protrusion causing mild effacement of the ventral thecal sac and moderate right foraminal stenosis. No significant cord compression.
- C6–C7: Mild disc bulge, no significant stenosis.
- C7–T1: Unremarkable.
- Paraspinal soft tissues: Within normal limits.

IMPRESSION:
1. C5–C6 broad-based right paracentral disc protrusion with moderate right foraminal stenosis, which may correlate with the patient’s right upper extremity symptoms.
2. Mild multilevel degenerative changes elsewhere without high-grade canal stenosis.

BILLING TABLE:

| Code   | Description                     | Units | Charge (USD) |
|--------|---------------------------------|-------|--------------|

Report Finalized: 04/12/2025 15:37
Electronic Signature: Jonathan P. Alvarez, MD
user_feedback: Don't include DOB, only age as of 1/1/2026. Always favor impressions over findings. We don't need to injection fluid details, only the injection site location. Use bullet points for listings.

medical_record:
ORTHOPEDIC SPINE CONSULTATION

Clinic: Austin Spine & Sports Specialists
Address: 1001 W Anderson Ln, Suite 300, Austin, TX 78757
Phone: 512-555-7711
Date of Service: 04/18/2025

Patient: Jonathan Parker
DOB: 03/22/1987
MRN: AS3-004821
Referring Physician: Laura Kim, MD
Insurer: Lone Star Auto & Casualty, Claim #LSA-2025-48192
Secondary: SilverShield Health PPO, Member ID SSH-77492038-01

CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Neck pain and right arm tingling following motor vehicle collision on 04/02/2025.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
37-year-old right-handed male presents for orthopedic evaluation. Since the collision on 04/02/2025, he has had persistent neck pain and intermittent tingling radiating from the right side of the neck into the lateral forearm and thumb. Pain averages 5/10, worsened by prolonged sitting at a computer and driving. He has started physical therapy (initial evaluation on 04/15/2025) with some improvement in range of motion but ongoing radicular symptoms.

Records reviewed today include: ED records from 04/02/2025, CT cervical spine, MRI cervical spine dated 04/12/2025 demonstrating C5–C6 right paracentral disc protrusion with moderate right foraminal stenosis.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Hypertension, hyperlipidemia.

EXAMINATION:
- Cervical range of motion limited by about 30% in extension and right rotation.
- Spurling maneuver positive on the right reproducing radicular symptoms.
- Motor strength: 5/5 bilateral deltoids, biceps, triceps, wrist extensors, grip.
- Reflexes: 2+ and symmetric, no pathologic reflexes.
- Sensation: Mildly decreased pinprick over right C6 dermatome.

ASSESSMENT:
1. C5–C6 right paracentral disc protrusion with C6 radiculopathy, post-traumatic (MVC 04/02/2025).
2. Cervical strain, subacute.

PLAN:
- Continue structured physical therapy 2–3 times per week for 6 additional weeks focusing on cervical stabilization, traction, and postural correction.
- Prescribe short course of oral steroids (methylprednisolone dose pack) to address inflammation.
- If symptoms persist or worsen beyond 6–8 weeks from today (i.e., after ~06/13/2025), consider cervical epidural steroid injection at C5–C6.
- Surgery (anterior cervical discectomy and fusion) discussed as a distant option if conservative measures fail; not indicated at this time.

WORK STATUS:
Patient may continue working with restrictions: no lifting >20 lbs, frequent micro-breaks from desk work, option to work from home 3 days/week through at least 05/30/2025.

BILLING SUMMARY:

| Code   | Description                                      | Units | Charge (USD) |
|--------|--------------------------------------------------|-------|--------------|
| 99244  | New Patient Consultation, Level 4                | 1     | 325.00       |
| 72040  | Cervical Spine X-ray, 2–3 views (in-office)      | 1     | 220.00       |

Provider: Daniel T. Wu, MD – Orthopedic Spine Surgeon (NPI: 1083749210)
Electronic Signature Date: 04/18/2025 14:26
user_feedback: Don't include DOB, only age as of 1/1/2026 which is 38. This summary should be concise and to the point. I prefer bullet points for listings.

PHYSICAL THERAPY INITIAL EVALUATION

Clinic: RenewMotion Physical Therapy
Address: 6701 Mesa Dr, Suite 210, Austin, TX 78731

Patient: Jonathan Parker

Referring Provider: Laura Kim, MD
Diagnosis Codes: M54.12 (Radiculopathy, cervical region), S13.4XXA (Sprain of ligaments of cervical spine, initial encounter), S23.3XXA (Sprain of ligaments of thoracic spine)

SUBJECTIVE:
Patient reports neck pain and right arm tingling since a rear-end car accident on 04/02/2025. He describes pain as 5/10 at worst, 2/10 at best. Pain is aggravated by desk work >45 minutes, driving, and reading in bed, and relieved by lying supine with a small towel under the neck. Denies current headaches.

OBJECTIVE:
Posture: Forward head posture, rounded shoulders.
Cervical ROM:
- Flexion: 40° (normal ~60°)
- Extension: 30° (normal ~75°)
- Rotation: R 45°, L 55°
Special Tests: Spurling test positive on right. Cervical distraction reduces radicular symptoms.
Strength: Mild weakness (4+/5) in right wrist extensors.

TREATMENT PLAN:
- Frequency: 2–3x/week for 6 weeks (from 04/15/2025 through approximately 05/27/2025).
- Interventions: Manual therapy (cervical traction, joint mobilizations), therapeutic exercises (deep neck flexor strengthening, scapular stabilization), postural training, home exercise program.

TODAY’S INTERVENTIONS (04/15/2025):
- Manual cervical traction, 10 minutes.
- Thoracic spine mobilizations, 8 minutes.
- Therapeutic exercise: chin tucks, scapular retraction, doorway stretch, 20 minutes.
- Home exercise program issued via email (to: jonathan.parker87@example.com).

medical_record:
PAIN MANAGEMENT CONSULTATION

Clinic: Hill Country Interventional Pain Center
Address: 4310 Medical Pkwy, Suite 310, Austin, TX 78756
Phone: 512-555-8822
Date of Service: 05/20/2025

Patient: Jonathan Parker
DOB: 03/22/1987
MRN: HCIP-778201
Referring Provider: Daniel T. Wu, MD (Orthopedic Spine)
Claim: Lone Star Auto & Casualty, Claim #LSA-2025-48192

CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Persistent neck pain and intermittent right arm paresthesia following motor vehicle collision on 04/02/2025.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Patient states that despite approximately 5 weeks of physical therapy (starting on 04/15/2025) and oral medications (NSAIDs, brief steroid taper in late April 2025), he continues to experience 3–6/10 neck pain and intermittent right arm tingling. He notes that pain limits his ability to work at the computer more than 6 hours per day, drive long distances (>30–40 minutes), and engage in recreational activities such as playing catch with his son.

He denies bowel/bladder dysfunction, progressive weakness, or gait disturbance.

PRIOR STUDIES:
- CT Cervical Spine (04/02/2025): No acute fracture; mild C5–C6 degenerative changes.
- MRI Cervical Spine (04/12/2025): C5–C6 broad-based right paracentral disc protrusion with moderate right foraminal stenosis, correlating with C6 radiculopathy.

ASSESSMENT:
1. C5–C6 disc protrusion with right C6 radiculopathy, following MVC on 04/02/2025.
2. Chronic cervical pain, partially responsive to conservative care.

PLAN:
- Recommend fluoroscopy-guided cervical epidural steroid injection (CESI) at C5–C6 level.
- Discussed risks (bleeding, infection, nerve injury, transient increased pain, steroid side effects) and benefits. Patient consents to proceed.
- Continue physical therapy and home exercise program before and after injection.
- Will re-evaluate 2–3 weeks after CESI, tentatively planned for early June 2025.
